717526f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, south from, but not including, 47th Street. In the centre background is the New York Theatre, which will stand until 1935. Below it is the Hotel Cadillac. In the right background is the Hotel Astor, and below it, a part of the New York
Times Building.
May, 1909.
Brown Brothers.

717531f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, north from 47th Street.  The entire block
from 47th to 48th Streets will stand in 1934.

May, 1909.

Brown Brothers.


Neg. #(?) 441

713300f-a.text:
47th Street, south side, west from 228 West 47th Street, west of
Broadway.
January 27, 1928.
P.L. Sperr.

713297f-a.text:
228-248 West 47th Street, south side, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. This is the Hotel Edison, a striking example of modernistic architecture. Herbert J. Krapp is the architect.
About 1930.
Albert Rothschild.

717532f-a.text:
1570-1564 Broadway, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of West 47th Street. The 2-story building comprises a double lot, Nos. 1570-1568, with the 11-story office building, No. 1564 adjoining. The Palace Theatre, a former vaudeville house now (1937), shows only motion pictures. Considering all the former aspirations of variety players to perform at this house, motion pictures are a tragedy. The theatre actually is in the 5-story building at the rear of both of these lots; with an entrance and lobby through the office building. These buildings, geographically on Seventh Ave., form a part of Times Square and bear Broadway numbers.
October 1, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

713298f-c.text:
West 47th Street, west from a point midway between Broadway and Eighth Ave., and across the latter, showing two theatres in the northern end of the block and facing each other. The Mansfield, and Biltmore Theatres bear Nos. 256 and 261 respectively. The building partially shown on the extreme left of No. 1 is the new Edison Hotel. The two tenement houses north of same bear Nos. 250 and 252. This set consists of two negative and two positive views.
September 1935.
W.P.A. Photo.

723553f-b.text:
(1 & 2)
Broadway, east side, south from West 47th Street, and showing the easterly portion of an area known as Times Square; a name received from the proximity of the Times Building, which appears in the center of this view. On the left is the Palace Theatre entrance, at No. 1564. This set
consists of a negative and a positive.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Ng 7i
(3 & 4)
A detail of same in the opposite direction and showing the entrance to Loew's State Theatre at No. 1538 Broadway. This set also consists of
a negative and a positive.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
No4S Neg 042

723539f-a.text:
Duffy Square: The recently erected Father Duffy monument. This individual was chaplain of the "Fighting 69th Regiment, New York National Guards" of World War fame. In the background is Broadway north of W. 47th Street.
September 22, 1939
George D. Chinn

717525f-c.text:
(1) Broadway, east side, at West 47th Street, showing the Palace Theatre (No. 1564 Broadway) and Loews Mayfair Theatre. The latter is technically on Seventh Ave., which at this point regains its identity after traversing Times Square. This is a set of two views, consisting of a negative and a positive.
September 1935.
W.P.A. Photo.

(2)The same and showing a more extensive view northward on Seventh
Ave. (left).
September 14, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

717529f.text:
Broadway (Times Square), east side, south across W. 47th Street. The Palace Theatre is on the left and the B. M. T. subway entrance
on the right.
1938-9
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y.' by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

717530f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, north from West 47th, to and including 48th Streets. Also shown is West 47th Street, at and adjoining the N.E.
corner of Broadway.
October 1, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

717535f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from 47th to 48th Streets. In the centre
is the Strand Theatre.
February 22, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
